channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Aerial War Over Ukraine Heats Up as Russia Pounds Cities
item.description: Ukraine, beefing up its air defenses, says Russia has bought ballistic missiles from Iran to replace the precision weapons it is firing at services vital to civilians.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Shashank Bengali and Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Bulent Kilic/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A Ukrainian artillery unit outside Bakhmut on Tuesday. After the Russian offensive slowed into a grinding strategy of shelling cities and towns, the Ukrainians needed more and better artillery. Now it is air defenses.

item.title: Our Changing World: The Climate Crisis in Pictures
item.description: No single image tells the story of a climate in crisis, but our photographers have come back from their global travels with an encyclopedia’s worth of pictures that hint at the scope and devastation.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fires.

item.title: After Decades of Resistance, Rich Countries Offer Direct Climate Aid
item.description: Several European leaders at COP27 announced funds to help poor nations recover from loss and damage caused by climate change. The United States was silent.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Mario Tama/Getty Images
item.media:description: Sandbags providing a barrier against rising seas in Funafuti, Tuvalu, in the South Pacific. Tuvalu’s prime minister, Kausea Natano, said on Tuesday that his nation was “the Pacific region’s champion of loss and damage.”

item.title: The World’s Democracies Ask: Why Can’t America Fix Itself?
item.description: Conversations across continents reveal alarm over the United States’ direction, as it slides away from ideals it once pressed other nations to adopt.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hundreds of Republican candidates this year have questioned the result of the 2020 presidential election or spread misinformation about it.

item.title: As Ukraine Bears Down, Life Worsens in Occupied Areas
item.description: Those fleeing speak of the growing dangers of bombardment and of Russian forces commandeering homes and sheltering among civilians.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall and Oleksandr Chubko
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Civilians who fled the Russian-controlled village of Kachkarivka arriving at a Ukrainian registration point last week.

item.title: Can South Africa Transition to Clean Energy?
item.description: A township’s battle over a new mine shows the challenge of a nation dependent on coal, but also desperate to leave it behind.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel, John Eligon and Joao Silva
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Joao Silva/The New York Times
item.media:description: A mine overlooking Phola township in Mpumalanga Province, South Africa’s coal region.

item.title: Somalis Are Going Hungry. Their Government Isn’t Calling It a Famine.
item.description: Humanitarian groups say Somalia’s leaders are resisting a formal declaration of famine that could unlock aid and save lives.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:credit: Andrea Bruce for The New York Times
item.media:description: In Baidoa, Somalia, an area gripped by hunger, Rahma Ali Ibrahim held her malnourished 1-year-old son, Zakaria Bashir, while they waited for medicine at the Horseed Health Center on Thursday.

item.title: French Cardinal’s Admission Renews Scrutiny of Church Sexual Abuse
item.description: A former archbishop of Bordeaux acknowledged that he had behaved “reprehensibly” with a 14-year-old girl over three decades ago, in the latest revelation to jolt Roman Catholics in France.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:credit: Mehdi Fedouach/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Cardinal Jean-Pierre Ricard, left, in 2017. He said his actions 35 years ago had “serious and lasting consequences” for the teenage girl.

item.title: Even as Egypt Hosts Climate Summit, Selling Fossil Fuels Is a Priority
item.description: Desperate for cash as the fallout from the Ukraine war batters its economy, Egypt has been conserving natural gas at home to sell to Europe.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:credit: Khaled Desouki/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Ursula von der Leyen, the president of the European Commission, second from left, with Tarek el-Molla, Egypt’s minister of petroleum, in June, after signing a deal for Egypt and Israel to export natural gas to Europe.

item.title: Kenya Discloses Part of Secret Railway Contract With China
item.description: The publication of details of a 2014 loan agreement for a cross-country train fulfilled a campaign vow by President William Ruto and revealed Beijing’s tough terms.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:credit: Brian Otieno for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Standard Gauge Railway inside the Nairobi National Park in 2021. Construction on the project began five years ago and has cost $4.7 billion.

item.title: Team Melli Once United Iran at World Cup. Now It Reflects Its Divisions.
item.description: Team Melli was long seen as a unifying force in a fractious nation. As it heads to the World Cup, it has become ensnared in its country’s internal politics.
item.dc:creator: Jeré Longman and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Leonhard Foeger/Reuters
item.media:description: Iran’s national soccer team, known as Team Melli, before a friendly against Uruguay in September.

item.title: Here’s What Happened on Tuesday at the COP27 Climate Summit
item.description: Scotland offered compensation funds to vulnerable nations and other countries follow suit with more cash. That raises the pressure on big countries like the United States.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Mohammed Salem/Reuters
item.media:description: World leaders are meeting in Sharm el Sheikh, Egypt, for two weeks of climate negotiations.

item.title: Ukraine Warns Russia Is Seeking Iranian Missiles as Battle in Skies Escalates
item.description: Ukrainian officials are celebrating the arrival of advanced Western air-defense systems but claim Russia is on the hunt for more powerful weapons.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A tram in Kyiv on Monday, as the capital still struggles with electricity supply.

item.title: How Belize Cut Its Debt by Fighting Global Warming
item.description: Developing nations are reducing their debt by pledging to protect their resources in financial deals that could give them a bigger role in the fight against climate change.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Meridith Kohut

item.title: Ukraine’s New Air Defense System Comes With a Deep Supply of Ammunition
item.description: The two NASAMS launchers delivered to Kyiv fire common air-to-air missiles used by its allies.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay
item.media:credit: Toms Kalnins/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Military planners decided that the air defense systems NASAMS would be especially useful for Ukraine: The ground-based launcher can fire missiles that were built for fighter jets in aerial combat.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: The U.S. Votes
item.description: Plus Europe makes climate pledges and Kenya discloses details of a Chinese railroad contract.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Adam Perez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A polling station in Norwalk, Calif., on Tuesday.

item.title: Europeans stick by Ukraine, despite mounting challenges.
item.description: Inflation and anxiety over nuclear weapons may be eating into some popular support for the war, but key governments remain insulated from the pressures for now.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz and Catherine Porter
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Andreas Rentz
item.media:description: James Cleverly, left, the British foreign secretary; Antonio Tajani, the Italian foreign minister; Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken; Catherine Colonna, the French foreign minister; and Annalena Baerbock, the German foreign minister, on Friday in Muenster, Germany, during a Group of 7 meeting.

item.title: Zelensky Tells Climate Meeting Russia’s War Undercuts Needed Action
item.description: Reports from the ground and research on previous armed conflicts suggest that the ecological impact of the conflict could be enormous.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky
item.media:credit: Ahmad Gharabli/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine delivering a video address to the COP27 climate conference in Sharm el Sheikh, Egypt, on Tuesday.

item.title: Setting a Kahlo Drawing Aflame in Search of an NFT Spark
item.description: It’s tough to profit in the struggling market of blockchain assets right now. Burning a purported drawing from Frida Kahlo’s personal diary didn’t help a businessman’s cause.
item.dc:creator: Zachary Small

item.title: Draft Report Offers Starkest View Yet of U.S. Climate Threats
item.description: “The things Americans value most are at risk,” says a draft of the National Climate Assessment, a major federal scientific report slated for release next year.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer and Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Jack Dempsey/Associated Press
item.media:description: A home destroyed by the Marshall fire in Louisville, Colo., in December. The United States has warmed 68 percent faster than Earth as a whole over the past 50 years, according to a draft scientific report.

item.title: Your Election Day Guide
item.description: How to make sense of the results.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Brian Kaiser for The New York Times
item.media:description: Early voting in Columbus, Ohio on Sunday.

item.title: Rotted Vegetables and Rancid Milk No More, as a Bridge Replaces Ferries
item.description: Truck drivers used to wait for days before crossing the Gambia River by ferry, but a towering bridge has cut the transit time down to minutes, and brought Senegal and Gambia closer.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.media:credit: Carmen Abd Ali for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Senegambia Bridge, seen from an abandoned pier in Gambia last month.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: European countries are backing Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Finbarr O’Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: A funeral in Kharkiv for a Ukrainian soldier killed in an artillery strike.

item.title: Why Kherson, Bracing for Battle, Matters So Much to Russia and Ukraine
item.description: Both sides have given great weight to what happens in Kherson, a city of symbolic and strategic value, where conditions are increasingly dire for the thousands of people who remain.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Marc Santora and Carly Olson
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian reconnaissance unit last month in the Kherson region, where the country’s forces have advanced on territory Russia seized early in the war.

item.title: Greece to Ban Sale of Spyware After Government Is Accused of Surveillance
item.description: Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis announced the ban after a news report claimed that he had directed the use of spyware against prominent politicians and journalists, which he denied.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.media:credit: Costas Baltas/Reuters
item.media:description: Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis of Greece has acknowledged that state intelligence was monitoring an opposition party leader with a wiretap.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: The U.S. Midterms Loom
item.description: Plus a warning at COP27 and Kherson in distress.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Nic Antaya for The New York Times
item.media:description: A person filled out their absent voter ballot at the West Bloomfield Township Clerk’s Office in West Bloomfield Township, Mich., on Monday.

item.title: At COP27, World Leaders Urge Faster Action on Climate Change
item.description: On the first day of COP27, the U.N. climate talks, world leaders urged each other to move faster to cut the pollution that is warming the planet while recognizing the war in Ukraine’s global energy effects and the unequal effects of climate change to date.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Mohammed Abed/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Delegates arriving at the United Nations climate conference in Egypt’s Red Sea resort city of Sharm el Sheikh on Monday.

item.title: American Aid Worker Is Shot Dead in Baghdad
item.description: Security officials said that gunmen opened fire on the aid worker’s vehicle in a drive-by shooting in the central Baghdad neighborhood where he lived.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.media:credit: Sabah Arar/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Karrada neighborhood of Baghdad, where an American aid worker was killed.

item.title: To Understand New Extremism, Look to History
item.description: Some of the forces protecting European nations even as far-right candidates thrive are not in play in the United States, and particularly not within a Republican establishment vulnerable to a takeover.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:credit: Jordan Vonderhaar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Part of the crowd for a campaign speech by former President Donald Trump in South Texas in October.

item.title: Switzerland Is Paying Poorer Nations to Cut Emissions on Its Behalf
item.description: The agreements raise concerns that other countries will follow suit, delaying more difficult cuts of greenhouse gas emissions in wealthier nations.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Fabrice Coffrini/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Switzerland already gets the bulk of its electricity from renewable sources like hydroelectric power, making further emissions cuts tougher.

item.title: Italy Blocks Male Migrants From Leaving Rescue Ships
item.description: The new right-wing government appears to be taking a harder line with people who are picked up in the Mediterranean as they try to cross from Libya.
item.dc:creator: Gaia Pianigiani
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:credit: Vincenzo Circosta/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Migrants on board the Ocean Viking rescue ship in the Mediterranean Sea in international waters on Sunday.

item.title: Why Control of Kherson Is Important to Russia and Ukraine
item.description: Russian occupation officials may be reducing their presence in the southern city, but Ukraine says Moscow will still fight to retain it.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian reconnaissance unit last month in the Kherson region, where the country’s forces have advanced on territory Russia seized early in the war.

item.title: Does America Vote Too Much?
item.description: Elections have consequences that go beyond the results.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: Campaign signs in Columbus, Ohio last month.

item.title: The World’s Most-Visited Glaciers Could Soon Be Gone
item.description: The U.N.’s cultural agency warns that ice sheets on Kilimanjaro, in the Dolomites and in Yosemite may disappear by 2050, highlighting travel’s impact on climate change.
item.dc:creator: Maria Cramer
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.media:credit: Pierre Teyssot/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Among the glaciers that UNESCO, the U.N. cultural organization, says could disappear by 2050 are those in the Dolomites, like the one on Marmolada, the range’s highest peak, part of which collapsed in July.

item.title: Countries Made Bold Climate Promises Last Year. How Are They Doing?
item.description: At last year’s U.N. climate summit in Glasgow, world leaders pledged to halt deforestation, phase out fossil fuel subsidies and offer up more climate aid. Following through has been tough.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: The New York Times; Shutterstock

item.title: A Messy Marital Split Tarnishes a Roman Soccer Legend
item.description: Francesco Totti and Ilary Blasi once shared a storybook love. Now she’s hiding his Rolexes, and he’s holding hostage her Jimmy Choos.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Valery Hache/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Francesco Totti and Ilary Blasi in 2018 in Monaco.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: The 27th annual U.N. climate talks opened yesterday in Egypt.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Fareed Khan/Associated Press
item.media:description: Flooding in Sindh Province, Pakistan, in September. A third of the country was inundated by extreme rainfall.

item.title: Even as Challenges Mount, Europeans Stick by Ukraine
item.description: Inflation and anxiety over nuclear weapons may be eating into some popular support for the war, but key governments remain insulated from the pressures for now.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz and Catherine Porter
item.media:credit: Finbarr O’Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: The funeral of a Ukrainian soldier who was killed last month by Russian artillery was held on Thursday in Kharkiv, Ukraine. European support for Ukraine remains high after eight months of war.

item.title: Russia Looks to Private Militia to Secure a Victory in Eastern Ukraine
item.description: Wagner Group forces launched attacks from several directions on the city of Bakhmut, though analysts said seizing it would yield little strategic value.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Civilians on Saturday crossed what remained of a bridge that had been bombarded by Russia in Bakhmut in Ukraine’s Donetsk region.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: COP27 Begins
item.description: Plus India could be key to peace in Ukraine and a child’s death in China sparks new outrage over the zero Covid policy.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Rajat Gupta/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Only a few people risked outdoor exercise in New Delhi on Thursday.

item.title: Michael Basman, Chess Master Known for ‘Bad’ Openings, Dies at 76
item.description: His opening repertoire was often successful. But it should have carried a label: “Do not try these at home (or at least not in important competitions).”
item.dc:creator: Dylan Loeb McClain
item.media:credit: U.P.I., via Getty Images
item.media:description: Michael Basman at the 1967-68 Hastings chess tournament in England. He used an unusual repertoire of opening moves because he wanted to avoid the well-traveled roads that most other top players followed.

item.title: Russian State Media Confirms That a Top General Is No Longer in His Post
item.description: Col. Gen. Alexander Lapin had been publicly bashed by a close ally of President Vladimir V. Putin over his performance in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd and Oleg Matsnev
item.media:credit: Maksim Bogodvid/Sputnik, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Colonel General Alexander Lapin in 2021.

item.title: Climate Conference to Debate Whether Rich Nations Will Pay for Damage
item.description: For the first time, the conference agenda will officially include the divisive issue of compensation by large nations responsible for the bulk of emissions.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.media:credit: Sean Gallup/Getty Images
item.media:description: Delegates to the international climate talks, known as COP27, on Sunday in Sharm El Sheikh, Egypt.

item.title: Ela Bhatt, Advocate for Women Workers in India, Dies at 89
item.description: The cooperative she founded has helped millions of women who had never before had a safety net. “They were,” she said, “the poorest among the poor.”
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:credit: David Karp/Associated Press
item.media:description: Ela Bhatt in 2006. The women’s organization she started in the 1970s now has more than two million members from India and neighboring countries.

item.title: Taiwan’s Bomb Shelters: ‘A Space for Life. And a Space for Death.’
item.description: Preparing for war over hundreds of years has left a mark on the island, with its hundreds of bomb shelters. Some are being turned into cultural oases.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: A bunker that has been converted into a temple in Keelung, Taiwan.

item.title: What’s at Stake
item.description: Tuesday’s elections will determine the next two years of President Biden’s agenda — and shape the future of democracy.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Clockwise from top left: Bridget Bennett, Audra Melton, and Nicole Craine for The New York Times
item.media:description: Clockwise from top left: Las Vegas, Athens, Ga., and Atlanta this weekend.

item.title: Could India Help Broker Peace in Ukraine?
item.description: India has good relations with both Russia and the West, and seeks a more muscular role in geopolitics. The biggest obstacle is that Ukrainians and Russians don’t want to talk.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman and Mujib Mashal
item.media:credit: Kevin Dietsch/Getty Images
item.media:description: S. Jaishankar, India’s foreign minister, is traveling to Russia this week for meetings with Russian officials.

item.title: Russia Reactivates Its Trolls and Bots Ahead of Tuesday’s Midterms
item.description: Researchers have identified a series of Russian information operations to influence American elections and, perhaps, erode support for Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers
item.media:credit: Mstyslav Chernov/Associated Press
item.media:description: The St. Petersburg building that is said to be the site of the Russian Internet Research Agency. Cybersecurity researchers have tied the agency to a new Russian misinformation effort.

item.title: At COP27, Developing Nations Have a Message for Polluters: Pay Up
item.description: Poor countries facing climate hazards want the United States and other industrialized nations to compensate them for the harm caused by greenhouse gases.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer, Lisa Friedman and Somini Sengupta
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Fareed Khan/Associated Press
item.media:description: Flooding in Sindh Province, Pakistan, in September. A third of the country was inundated by extreme rainfall

item.title: The War in Ukraine Could Dent Russia’s Clout as an Arms Dealer
item.description: Analysts say Russia’s performance in Ukraine, coupled with Western sanctions, is likely to hurt its ability to sell weapons abroad. Southeast Asia is a case in point.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: At the International Military-Technical Forum in Moscow in August. Russia is the world’s second largest arms exporter after the United States.

item.title: Kyiv Planning for Total Evacuation if It Loses Electricity
item.description: The city is also establishing 1,000 heating centers for its 3 million residents, as Russia pounds away at civilian targets.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Ben Hubbard
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kyiv is facing rolling blackouts to help prevent a complete failure of Ukraine’s electrical grid.

item.title: Far Right’s Rise in Israel Driven by Anxiety and Fear
item.description: To win election, Benjamin Netanyahu and his far-right allies harnessed perceived threats to Israel’s Jewish identity after ethnic unrest last year and the subsequent inclusion of Arab lawmakers in the government.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of Benjamin Netanyahu last month during a Likud party rally in Sderot, Israel. A far-right alliance, Religious Zionism, has given back to Mr. Netanyahu his parliamentary majority.

item.title: Astronomers Find a Black Hole in Our Cosmic Back Yard
item.description: Just 1,600 light-years away, the black hole is the closest known to Earth. The good news: It’s dormant, at least for now.
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye
item.category: Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society (Journal)
item.media:credit: International Gemini Observatory/NOIRLab/NSF/AURA
item.media:description: An artist’s impression of the black hole and its companion star, a mere 1,600 light-years away from Earth.

item.title: Iran Acknowledges Sending Drones to Russia, but Says This Preceded War
item.description: Russia has used Iranian-made drones in a series of deadly strikes on Ukrainian cities, according to Ukrainian and Western officials.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rescue workers at a residential building in Kyiv, Ukraine, that was struck by a Russian drone attack in October.

item.title: North Korea Launches More Missiles
item.description: Tensions further escalated on the divided peninsula, with Washington deploying supersonic B-1B bombers for the first time in years as part of a military exercise.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: South Korean Defense Ministry, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Washington and Seoul participating in a joint military exercise over South Korea on Saturday in a photograph provided by the South Korean Defense Ministry.

item.title: Time Warp
item.description: How readers are adjusting to the end of daylight saving time.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Alleviating Canada’s Acute Shortage of Family Doctors
item.description: British Columbia announced a plan this week that will boost physicians’ incomes, but more changes may be necessary to increase nationwide access to family physicians.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Ian Austen/The New York Times
item.media:description: About 11 percent of Nova Scotians are without a family doctor.

item.title: Hosting Climate Summit Is Both Opportunity and Risk for Egypt
item.description: The COP27 meeting next week allows a debt-wracked African country to champion climate needs of poorer nations. But it also puts Egypt under scrutiny.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: The idyllic Red Sea resort town of Sharm el-Sheikh is set to host the 27th annual United Nations-sponsored climate summit, known as COP27.

item.title: These Men Fled War in Syria to Ukraine. Now They’ve Fled Again.
item.description: Two men displaced from Syria as civil war gripped their country spent a decade living in limbo in Ukraine. But when war came to them again, they were forced to leave, eventually making their way to London.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Muhsen Hamed, left, and Abdul Safwa, two Syrians who fled Ukraine at the start of the war there. Now in London, they face a complicated path toward rebuilding their lives.

item.title: Itaewon Goes Quiet After Deadly Crowd Crush in Seoul, South Korea
item.description: Itaewon was popular for its diversity and nightlife. A week after a disaster killed more than 150 young people there, the neighborhood is a monument of grief.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun and Chang W. Lee

item.title: What Can US Democracy Learn From Brazil?
item.description: Both nations had presidents who attacked their elections. But their responses — and the aftermaths — were much different.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of President Jair Bolsonaro blockaded a main road in São Paulo on Tuesday, one of many such protests around Brazil after he lost the election to Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva.

item.title: Republican Gains in Congress Would Pressure Biden on Ukraine and Iran
item.description: Officials in the Biden administration expect plenty of complications, including summons to hearings over the U.S. withdrawal from Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Kevin McCarthy said last month that a Republican-led House would be unwilling to approve “blank check” assistance for Ukraine.

item.title: The U.S. and Europe seek to assure Ukraine of support.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky, Andrew E. Kramer, Eric Schmitt, Helene Cooper and Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Engineers working on electrical lines along the railway in the southeastern Ukrainian town of Prudyanka. The Group of 7 nations said they would work together to rebuild critical infrastructure in Ukraine.

item.title: Russia Sends Ill-Trained Draftees Into Combat Amid Losses, Analysts Say
item.description: Ukraine’s military and Western analysts say Russian forces are making fruitless attacks in eastern Ukraine and taking heavy losses after a hastily arranged draft added over 300,000 troops.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Finbarr O’Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier salvaged parts from a destroyed Russian armored vehicle in the city of Kupiansk-Vuzlovyi in Ukraine’s northeastern Kharkiv region on Tuesday.
